messages.message:
FILE - Participants dance as they take part in the Celebrate Israel Parade Sunday, June 2, 2019, in New York.
A New York City parade for Israel that annually draws masses of people will step off Sunday with tight security and a stress on solidarity amid the war in Gaza.
(AP Photo/Craig Ruttle, file)NEW YORK – An annual New York City parade for Israel that draws thousands of people is scheduled to hit the streets Sunday with heightened security and a focus on solidarity during the war in Gaza.
The parade comes almost eight months after the unprecedented Oct. 7 attack by Hamas, the deadliest in Israel's history.
Israel faces growing international criticism for its strategy of systematic destruction in Gaza, at a huge cost in civilian lives.

NEW YORK (AP) — An annual New York City parade for Israel that draws thousands of people is scheduled to hit the streets Sunday with heightened security and a focus on solidarity during the war in Gaza.
The parade comes almost eight months after the unprecedented Oct. 7 attack by Hamas, the deadliest in Israel’s history.
There was never a thought of cancelling the parade this year, Treyger said, despite what he termed an astronomical rise in antisemitism.
“We’re not going to allow any unlawfulness and any disruption of any celebration of one’s heritage in this city,” New York City Mayor Eric Adams said at a security briefing.
Israel faces growing international criticism for its strategy of systematic destruction in Gaza, at a huge cost in civilian lives.

“We’re not going to allow any unlawfulness and any disruption of any celebration of one’s heritage in this city,” New York City Mayor Eric Adams said at a security briefing.

Parade for Israel in NYC focuses on solidarity this year as Gaza war casts a grim shadowParade for Israel in NYC focuses on solidarity this year as Gaza war casts a grim shadow View PhotoNEW YORK (AP) — An annual New York City parade for Israel that draws thousands of people is scheduled to hit the streets Sunday with heightened security and a focus on solidarity during the war in Gaza.
The parade comes almost eight months after the unprecedented Oct. 7 attack by Hamas, the deadliest in Israel’s history.
There was never a thought of cancelling the parade this year, Treyger said, despite what he termed an astronomical rise in antisemitism.
“We’re not going to allow any unlawfulness and any disruption of any celebration of one’s heritage in this city,” New York City Mayor Eric Adams said at a security briefing.

Sonja Puzic, The Canadian PressConvocation ceremonies for graduating University of Toronto students begin Monday against the backdrop of a pro-Palestinian encampment that has remained on campus for weeks despite a trespass notice and looming legal action.
More than 30 ceremonies are scheduled to take place through June 21 and the university says all events will proceed as planned with "extra precautions."
The University of Toronto said it takes the safety of graduating students and their guests “extremely seriously” and has a “well established” process to handle event disruptions.
An encampment at McGill University has been in place for more than a month, forcing the administration to move graduation ceremonies off campus to the Bell Centre, home of the Montreal Canadiens.
McGill president Deep Saini expressed frustration that encampment representatives walked away from the last meeting aimed at ending their protest.
